string_table.string: Skip Navigation. Hit enter to return to the slide.

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
The Active Lecture

Click on a title in the table of contents on the right for fast navigation to a specific topic. You can also use the next and back buttons at the bottom of the player to navigate through this presentation.

You may also click a link below to jump to the topic.

This presentation has sound, however, you can adjust or turn off the audio by clicking the sound icon on the bottom left of the player and dragging the slider up or down.

You can also read the transcript of the narration by clicking on the transcript tab next to the table of contents on the sidebar on the right.

Click on a link or click the next button to continue.

There are many differences between passive and active lecturing. In general, passive lecturing involves non-participatory activities whereas active lecturing makes students do something. Active lecturing is all about learning by doing rather than simply receiving the information.

Lecturing can be a powerful tool to do many things including summarizing new material, posing thoughtful questions for investigation, demonstrating an expert’s way of analyzing subject matter and it can be used to adapt information for students of varying ability and prior knowledge.

While it’s not an exact number, the 85% rule can be useful in planning and giving lectures. It states that if you let them, students will come up with about 85% of the material that you are going to present to them. Your job as an active lecturer is to find out what they know and fill in the remaining 15%.

Click on the link to view a video about this idea.

The Learning Pyramid is a visual display of how likely learners are to remember material based on the activity they did to learn it.

While the numbers are somewhat debatable, the important thing to take away from the Learning Pyramid is that you should combine traditional passive teaching methods with more participatory activities such as Group Discussion, Hands-On Practice and Teaching Others. All of these teaching methods can be both useful and effective for learning but combining some participatory activities into your lecture will help make it more active.

Strategies & Techniques

Click on the strategies and techniques to view more information about each of them.

Provide a shell of content to students at the beginning of the lecture to help them follow along and complete as they find out the missing information.

You can use Advance Organizers with printed PowerPoint slides with blanks, incomplete graphs, diagrams or images, mind maps, venn diagrams and KWL charts.

For more information, examples and a video explanation, click on the links below, or click back to return to the strategies and techniques slide.

1. Put students in groups and assign each group a task or activity.

2. Give students time to work on their tasks as a group.

3. Assign each person a number or color and form new groups based on this.

4. Each member teaches or reports what their previous group came up with to the new group.

Classroom response devices such as clickers or mobile applications like Kahoot or Poll Everywhere allow students to respond anonymously and in real-time to take surveys, complete informal low-stakes assessments, involve students in the lecture and can be used with cell phones and tablets.

For more information, click on the link below, or click back to return to the strategies and techniques slide.

Group Research and Response is an activity where during the lecture, you pose a higher order thinking or HOT question and have students pair up or work in small groups to research or develop a response.

For more information, click on the links below, or click back to return to the strategies and techniques slide.

If the lesson involves a multi-faceted concept, you can use Jigsaw Groups to divide the work and implement peer-instruction.

Click on the link to see a demonstration of Jigsaw Groups

For more information, click on the links below, or click back to return to the strategies and techniques slide.

Include a slide in your presentation that highlights the most important points of the lecture that are worth keeping. Ask students to explain why these points are key.

You could also use the think-pair-share technique with this activity or ask students to come up with what they think are the key-pers of the lesson.

Click back to return to the strategies and techniques slide.

Students take 1 minute to write down all of the important points they have learned so far in the lecture.

Collect the papers to see if students are on the right track or if there are any concepts that should be reinforced.

You can also use this as an entry or exit ticket.

For more information and examples click on the links below, or click back to return to the strategies and techniques slide.

Have students write down the concept that is most confusing to them. Then collect the papers and respond through re-teaching or posting the answers on Canvas.

You can also use this as an entry or exit ticket or group students to ask them to try to explain or answer questions together.

For more information and examples click on the links below, or click back to return to the strategies and techniques slide.

Students nominate a concept that is not clear to them and the majority affirm the concepts that are the most important to review.

You can use this with student response devices, think-pair-share or with the group research and response technique.

Click back to return to the strategies and techniques slide.

Following the reading of or listening to material, students predict the next action or reaction in the text or lesson and explain why.

Scenarios further this by allowing students to choose between given options and view the consequence of each action.

For more information and examples click on the links below, or click back to return to the strategies and techniques slide.

During the lecture, give students a non-graded set of quiz questions.

Students will then respond to the questions individually and then share their responses with a partner for confirmation or clarification.

Then the quiz is repeated.

For more information click on the link below, or click back to return to the strategies and techniques slide.

Students are asked to take a moment to reflect on what they have just learned and identify a connection to their own prior knowledge.

You can use this with think-pair-share or to start group discussions.

For more information click on the link below, or click back to return to the strategies and techniques slide.

Students take a moment to share notes with a partner to identify what they wrote down and why.

This can be done in groups or during think-pair-share.

Click back to return to the strategies and techniques slide.

Students reflect on a question you provide them. Then they pair up with a partner and share their responses.

For more information click on the links below, or click back to return to the strategies and techniques slide.

Students take a moment to summarize the most important points of the lecture.

This can be done individually or in groups.

Click back to return to the strategies and techniques slide.

Resources & Related Topics

Click on the links to view more information about each of the topics.

You may also be interested in related mini-modules such as the Flipped Classroom and How to Avoid Death by PowerPoint.
